15.verse: Meanwhile Absalom and all his people, the men of Israel, came into Jerusalem; and Ahithophel was with him.

16.verse: When Hushai the Archite, David’s friend, came to Absalom, he saluted Absalom. Hushai: Long live the king! Long live the king!

17.verse: Absalom: Is this how you repay my father’s friendship? Wouldn’t it be better for you to have followed him?

18.verse: Hushai: No. I will serve the one whom the Eternal One, these people, and the people of Israel have chosen. I’ll serve him and remain with him.

19.verse: And why shouldn’t I serve the son of my lord? Just as I served him, I will serve you.

20.verse: Absalom (to Ahithophel): Advise me. What should I do now?

21.verse: Ahithophel: Make the break with your father complete. Sleep with each woman in your father’s harem whom he left behind to mind the palace. All of Israel will hear how you’ve insulted your father, and they’ll know there’s no turning back now. They will have to be committed to this rebellion.

22.verse: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof of the palace, and all Israel saw that Absalom had slept with his father’s concubines.

23.verse: In those days, both with David and then with Absalom, Ahithophel’s counsel was deemed so wise that it could have come from God Himself, so his advice was highly prized.

1.verse: Ahithophel had a strategy for victory over David and advised Absalom. Ahithophel: Let me choose 12,000 men, and tonight we will pursue David

2.verse: while he is weak and weary. We’ll throw him into a panic; then all of the people will run away from him, come back to you, and be safe. I will strike down the king. If we take only the life of this one man here—your father—then everyone else can return to you.

3.verse: while he is weak and weary. We’ll throw him into a panic; then all of the people will run away from him, come back to you, and be safe. I will strike down the king. If we take only the life of this one man here—your father—then everyone else can return to you.

4.verse: This advice appealed to Absalom and to Israel’s elders.

5.verse: Absalom: Call in Hushai the Archite, and see what he thinks.

6.verse: When Hushai arrived, Absalom told him what Ahithophel had advised. Absalom: What do you think? Should we do as he suggests? If not, tell us what you’d advise.

7.verse: Hushai: I don’t think the advice from Ahithophel is good this time, and I’ll tell you why:

8.verse: You know that your father and his men are hardened soldiers. Right now they’re angry, like a bear that’s been robbed of her cubs in the field. Also your father is such a wise warrior that he’ll know he’s our target. He won’t sleep in the same camp with his people.

9.verse: He’s probably hidden in a cave or some other hole where he will be hard to find. When our troops start dying in the first attack, everyone will say, “Absalom’s men are being slaughtered.”

10.verse: Then even the courageous warriors, the ones with the courage of lions, will disintegrate in fear. Everyone in Israel knows that your father is a true warrior, and those with him are hardened veterans.

11.verse: No, my counsel is to take your time. Gather the people of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, so that you have a large army, like the grains of sand on the beach, and lead them into battle yourself.

12.verse: Wherever David is, we will fall on him like the dew on the ground. We’ll kill him and all who defend him. No one will remain.

13.verse: And if he slips into a fortified city, we’ll have so many men of Israel that we could lasso that city and pull it down into the valley, so that not even a stone would be left in place.

14.verse: Absalom and his counselors decided that Hushai’s plan was better than Ahithophel’s, not knowing that the Eternal One had determined to thwart Ahithophel’s good advice and bring about Absalom’s destruction.

15.verse: After Hushai advised Absalom, he went to the priests Zadok and Abiathar. He wasn’t certain what Absalom would do, so he told them Ahithopel’s plan and his own.

16.verse: Hushai: Quickly now, send a messenger to David. Tell the king to move deeper into the wilderness, across the river but away from the fords! If he remains where he is tonight, then he and all his followers will be swallowed by Absalom’s forces.

17.verse: The priests’ sons, Jonathan and Ahimaaz, were waiting at En-rogel for news. A servant girl would bring them messages because they couldn’t risk being seen entering the city. When they had something to report, they would go tell King David.

18.verse: But this time they were careless, and a boy saw them and reported it to Absalom. So the two men fled to the house of a man in Bahurim. There was a well in the courtyard, and they lowered themselves into it.

19.verse: The man’s wife put the cover over the well and spread out grain on top of it, so no one could see it was there.

20.verse: When Absalom’s soldiers arrived, they questioned her. Soldiers: Where are the traitors Ahimaaz and Jonathan? Wife: Oh, they’ve crossed to the other side of the stream. The soldiers looked for them, but when they couldn’t find them, they returned to Jerusalem.

21.verse: After the soldiers left, they climbed out of the well and went to speak to King David. Ahimaaz and Jonathan: Get ready to cross over the river into the wilderness quickly, because here is Ahithophel’s plan of action.

22.verse: And knowing about the danger, David and everyone with him crossed over the Jordan River and moved deep into the wilderness. By daybreak not a single man loyal to David was left on the near side of the Jordan.

23.verse: When Ahithophel saw that his plan was ignored, he knew the best hope for victory was lost. He saddled his donkey and went home; and after setting his affairs in order, he hanged himself and died. He was buried within his father’s tomb.

24.verse: Meanwhile David went on to Mahanaim as Absalom was crossing over the Jordan with all of the men of Israel.

25.verse: Absalom had made Amasa commander of the army, which used to be Joab’s office. Amasa was a nephew of David: his father was Ithra the Israelite who had married Abigail, Nahash’s daughter and also a sister of David and Zeruiah, Joab’s mother.

26.verse: Absalom and the army of Israel camped on the plains of Gilead.

27.verse: When David arrived in Mahanaim, Shobi (the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites), Machir (the son of Ammiel from Lo-debar), and Barzillai the Gileadite (from Rogelim)

28.verse: brought beds, basins, earthenware, wheat, barley, meal, parched seeds and grain, beans, lentils,

29.verse: honey, butter, sheep, and local cheese for David and his men to eat; for they knew the men were hungry, tired, and thirsty there in the wilderness.

1.verse: Then David gathered the soldiers who were with them and divided them into units of a thousand and a hundred. He appointed leaders over each unit.

2.verse: He divided his army into three groups. A third of them were commanded by Joab, a third by Abishai (Zeruiah’s son, Joab’s brother), and the final third by Ittai the Gittite. David (to his soldiers): I will go out to fight with you.

3.verse: Soldiers: No, you should remain in Mahanaim. If we flee, the people here will not be concerned about us; or if half of us die, they will not care. But they care about you. You’re worth 10,000 of us. It’s better that you stay here and help us from the city.

4.verse: David: All right. I’ll do what you think is best. David is torn between his duties as king and his duties as father. When his own son attempts to overthrow him, he is forced to flee his kingdom and is subjected to ridicule and contempt. Absalom sleeps with all the royal concubines, a deadly insult, and it looks as though David will be overthrown just as Saul was before him. Even now with Absalom leading an outright rebellion, dishonoring his father, and seeking his death, David seeks to spare his son. So David stood beside the gate while his soldiers marched out to fight against Absalom, organized into fighting units by the hundreds and by the thousands.

5.verse: Then David instructed his generals Joab, Abishai, and Ittai. David: For my sake, be merciful to the young man Absalom. Now everyone had heard about David’s instructions to the commanders concerning Absalom.

6.verse: Then the army went out to fight against Israel, and the battle was fought in the wooded areas of Ephraim.

7.verse: David’s forces won a great victory against Absalom’s men, and 20,000 men were killed in the battle that day.

8.verse: The battle spread all across the landscape, and more of his opponents were lost to the forest than to the sword.

9.verse: David takes the fight into a forested area rather than staying out in the open field. Since his army is more experienced in fighting in such terrain, there is an opportunity for a smaller force to defeat a larger one. Absalom’s men (and Absalom himself, as illustrated in the following verses) die as a result of not knowing how to fight in the forest and avoid its pitfalls. Absalom himself encountered David’s forces, and as he was riding away on his mule, the animal took him into the thick overhanging branches of a huge oak tree. There his hair was caught, and he dangled between the sky and earth as his mule fled from underneath him.

10.verse: A soldier saw this and told Joab. Soldier: I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree, helpless.

11.verse: Joab: You saw Absalom? Then why didn’t you kill him while he was hanging there? I would have given you 10 pieces of silver and a belt!

12.verse: Soldier: If you put 1,000 pieces of silver into my hand, I wouldn’t raise it against the king’s son. We all heard the king say to you generals, “For my sake, protect young Absalom.”

13.verse: If I had taken his life despite that, you would stand back and watch as they strung me up. Nothing is hidden from the king.

14.verse: Joab: I can’t stand here talking to you all day. Joab took three spears, and finding Absalom still dangling by his hair inside the oak, he thrust them into his heart.

15.verse: Ten young men, Joab’s armor bearers, surrounded Absalom then and struck him until he was dead.

16.verse: Then Joab sounded the trumpet and pulled back the soldiers from their pursuit of the army of Israel, because Joab knew no good would come of further fighting.

17.verse: They took Absalom’s body and threw it in a deep hole in the forest, and then they stacked stones high over it. Meanwhile the remaining Israelites loyal to Absalom fled to their homes.

18.verse: Before his death, Absalom had erected a monument to himself in the King’s Valley, since he had no son to keep his memory alive. He named the monument after himself, and Absalom’s Monument still stands in the King’s Valley.

19.verse: After Absalom’s death, Ahimaaz, Zadok’s son, spoke to Joab. Ahimaaz: Let me hurry to the king with the good news that the Eternal One has given him victory over his enemies.

20.verse: Joab: You’re not going to carry news today. Maybe some other day, but not today, for today the news that matters most is that the king’s son is dead.

21.verse: (to the Cushite) Go and tell the king what you have seen. The Cushite bowed in obedience to Joab, then he began running to bring the news to David.

22.verse: Ahimaaz: Whatever happens, I want to run after the Cushite. Joab: Why would you want to follow, even though you have nothing to gain?

23.verse: Ahimaaz: Regardless of what happens, I am going to run. Joab: OK, then. Run. Ahimaaz ran, and going by way of the plain, he outran the Cushite.

24.verse: Now David sat waiting between the gates. A guard went up to the roof of the gates by the wall, and he saw a man running toward them.

25.verse: He shouted to alert the king, and David responded. David: If he is alone, he comes with good news. As the messenger drew near,

26.verse: the guard saw a second man running. Guard (to the gatekeeper): Another man is running by himself. David: Then he also has good news.

27.verse: Guard: From the way he runs, I’d say the first one is Ahimaaz, Zadok’s son. David: He is a good man, and he comes bearing good news.

28.verse: And as Ahimaaz approached, he shouted to the king. Ahimaaz: All is well! He dropped to honor the king, his face to the ground. Ahimaaz: Praise the Eternal One, your True God, who has given us victory over those who raised their hands against you, my lord and king.

29.verse: David: But how is my son Absalom? Ahimaaz: When Joab sent me, your servant, there was still an uproar; but I don’t know what was happening.

30.verse: David: Make way for this next messenger. Move over here. Ahimaaz turned aside, keeping still and quiet.

31.verse: So the Cushite arrived and greeted the king. Cushite: I have good news, my lord and king! The Eternal has today taken your side and delivered you from all those who rose up against you!

32.verse: David: But what about young Absalom? Cushite: May all your enemies and all those who wish the king harm be as that young man is now!

33.verse: Then the king was stricken with grief. He went to a chamber over the gateway and wept as he went. David: O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!

1.verse: David should never be counted out. Hours before, Absalom has everything going his way, and David is run out of his kingdom. Smart and fierce, he doesn’t spend all those years hiding from Saul and fighting with little or no resources for nothing. Although he orders his generals to be merciful to his son Absalom, his forces win a great victory against the rebel forces, and David’s general Joab kills Absalom and removes a threat to the security of the kingdom. But David’s reaction again is tender; although his son might have killed him if he’d been given the chance, David laments his death. As king, as father, and as follower of the Lord, he knows he could have done better; but now it is too late, and all he can do is mourn the consequences of his past actions. Joab heard the news that David was weeping and mourning for Absalom,

2.verse: and the mood shifted from celebration to sorrow, for all the soldiers heard that the king was grieving for his son.

3.verse: They crept back to the city as though they had lost the battle rather than saved the kingdom.

4.verse: The king covered his face, and he continued to cry loudly. David: O my son Absalom. O Absalom, my son, my son!

5.verse: Then Joab came into the king’s presence. Joab: Today you have shamed the men who saved your life, who have saved the lives of your sons and daughters, and the lives of your wives and concubines,

6.verse: all because of your love for those who hated you and your hatred of those who love you! You’ve made it perfectly clear where your affections are—that your officers and men mean nothing to you, and that you’d gladly trade our lives for Absalom’s.

7.verse: Go out now, and speak with kindness and respect to those who have served you. You can still save the day; but I swear by the Eternal One, if you do not alter this mood now, not a single man will be with you tonight, and this will be the greatest disaster ever to wash over you.

8.verse: Then the king got up, went outside, and sat down inside the gate where Absalom had acquired his allies. When the people heard that the king had come out to them, they gathered around him. The men of Israel who had gone against the king, meanwhile, had fled to their homes.

9.verse: Throughout Israel, from tribe to tribe, people were debating: “David saved us from our enemies and took us out of the hands of the Philistines, but he fled from Absalom.

10.verse: Now Absalom, whom we appointed to lead us, has fallen in battle. Why, then, haven’t we moved to bring the king back to power?”

11.verse: David knew about this groundswell of support, and he sent a message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar. David: Tell the leaders of Judah, “Why should you be the last to agree to bring the king back? Everyone in Israel is talking about it, even in the king’s own house.

12.verse: And you—you are my flesh and my bones. Why should you be the last to join this movement?”

13.verse: And tell Amasa, who joined the rebellion against me, “Aren’t you my flesh and my bone? May God bring disaster on me if I don’t allow you to serve as commander of my army from now on in place of Joab.”

14.verse: Amasa persuaded all of Judah to stand united supporting David, and they sent word that he and his servants should come back.

15.verse: So the king came back to the Jordan River. The people of Judah turned out to meet him at Gilgal, and they celebrated as he crossed back over the Jordan into his kingdom.

16.verse: Shimei (son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim), who had abused David on his way into exile, was one of those in the throngs hurrying to meet David.

17.verse: He joined 1,000 people from Benjamin. Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul who had spoken with David on his way into exile, and his 15 sons and 20 servants who also hurried down to the Jordan before the king,

18.verse: kept crossing the ford to assist in moving the king’s household and was anxious to help in any other way. Then Shimei, the son of Gera, fell in front of the king before he crossed the Jordan.

19.verse: Shimei: Please, my lord, don’t hold me guilty or hold a grudge for what I did against you on the day you left Jerusalem, cursing you and throwing stones at you. May the king forget it ever happened!

20.verse: I, your servant, know that what I did was wrong. That’s why I’ve come today, to be the first of all the house of Joseph to greet my king.

21.verse: Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, remembered Shimei well. Abishai: My lord, shouldn’t Shimei be executed for cursing the Eternal’s anointed king with such contempt?

22.verse: David: What business is that of yours, sons of Zeruiah? Why should you make yourself my opponent? Will I execute anyone in Israel on a day like this? Don’t I know that today I am the king of Israel?

23.verse: (to Shimei) You will not die. I swear it.

24.verse: Mephibosheth, the lame grandson of Saul and son of David’s dear friend Jonathan, also made his way to meet the king. His feet had not been cared for—no, and his beard had grown long, and he had not had his clothes washed—since the king went into exile and returned in peace.

25.verse: When he met the king in Jerusalem, the king received him. David: Why didn’t you go into exile with me, Mephibosheth?

26.verse: Mephibosheth: My lord, my servant Ziba tricked me. I asked him to saddle a donkey so that I could go with you—for you know I cannot walk.

27.verse: He has told you lies about me, but my lord is like a heavenly messenger of God. So do what seems right to you, and I will accept it.

28.verse: You had the right to kill everyone in my family when you became king, yet you took me to sit at your table. So it would be wrong for me to bicker over anything with you.

29.verse: David: Let’s not talk any more about this. I have decided that you and Ziba will share the land.

30.verse: Mephibosheth: My king, let him take it all. I’m just grateful you are back safely in your own palace and kingdom.

31.verse: Barzillai from Gilead, who had fed the king’s forces, had come down from Rogelim to escort the king across the Jordan.

32.verse: He was 80 years old and very wealthy, which is how he had been able to provide for the king while he was at Mahanaim.

33.verse: David (to Barzillai): Cross over with me, and come to Jerusalem. I’ll take care of you and give you a place of honor at my side.

34.verse: Barzillai: My king, how many years do I have left, that I should leave my home and relocate with the king to Jerusalem? I am too old for court life.

35.verse: I am 80 years old today. My judgment is not as good as it used to be. I can’t taste my food, enjoy my drink, or even hear the pleasant singing of men and women. So why should you burden yourself with me, my lord and king?

36.verse: I will travel a little farther with you across the Jordan, but you don’t owe me anything more for my hospitality. Why should you, my king, offer me such a handsome reward?

37.verse: Please grant me your favor to return home, to die among my own people near the resting places of my parents. But do consider your servant Chimham. Let him come with you, and may you honor Chimham as you see fit.

38.verse: David: Chimham will cross the river with me, and I will treat him as seems good to you. Anything you want from me, I will do for you.

39.verse: Then the king and all the people crossed over the Jordan. David kissed Barzillai and wished him well, and Barzillai returned home.

40.verse: The king, along with Chimham, went on to Gilgal, accompanied by all the people of Judah and half the people of Israel.

41.verse: Then the people of Israel came in front of the king, indignant. People of Israel: Why have our kinsmen of Judah stolen you away from us and helped you across the Jordan? Why have they brought across your family and your subjects and all your men?

42.verse: People of Judah: Because we are more closely related to the king than you are. Why are you upset about this? Has the king fed us at his expense? Has he given to us anything he has not given to you?

43.verse: People of Israel: We have 10 shares in the office of the king because there are 10 of our tribes in Israel and only 2 of yours—Judah and Benjamin. And we have more shares in David as the king than you do for the same reason. Why were you angry with us? Weren’t we the first to talk about bringing David home? But the people of Judah were harsher than the people of Israel.

1.verse: A worthless troublemaker, Sheba the Benjaminite, the son of Bichri, blasted a trumpet and silenced everyone. Sheba: We don’t have any share in David, no interest in the son of Jesse! Israel, let’s go back to our tents and show loyalty to only our own tribes!

2.verse: So the people of Israel stopped following David and followed Sheba, son of Bichri; but the people of Judah faithfully accompanied David back from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

3.verse: David came back to his palace at Jerusalem, and he took the 10 members of his harem he had left behind to look after things—the concubines whom Absalom had used sexually—and put them away in a house, under guard. He took care of them, but he never slept with them again as long as they lived. They lived shut away as if they were widows.

4.verse: David (to Amasa): Go and tell the men of Judah they have three days to get here, and you come with them.

5.verse: So Amasa went out to call Judah together, but he was delayed beyond his deadline.

6.verse: David (to Abishai): Sheba, Bichri’s son, will do more damage to us than Absalom if he’s left untouched. Take my men and pursue him. If we’re not careful, he’ll escape into a fortified city and continue to cause trouble.

7.verse: So Joab took his troops with the mercenary corps of Cherethites and Pelethites, and all these warriors went from Jerusalem in pursuit of Sheba, Bichri’s son.

8.verse: When they reached the great boulder at Gibeon, Amasa met them. Joab was dressed for battle, with his sword strapped on at the waist; and as he went forward to meet Amasa, Joab’s sword slipped out of its sheath.

9.verse: Joab: How are you, my brother? With his right hand, Joab held Amasa’s face to kiss him,

10.verse: but Amasa did not see the sword in Joab’s left hand. With one motion, Joab ripped open Amasa’s belly; his intestines spilled onto the ground, and he died. Then Joab and his brother Abishai went off in pursuit of Sheba, Bichri’s son.

11.verse: One of Joab’s men stood by Amasa’s body and shouted, Joab’s Soldier: If you’re for Joab and David, then follow Joab!

12.verse: Amasa lay agonizing in his blood on the highway, and the soldier saw that everyone was stopping to look. He dragged Amasa off the road into a field and threw a coat over him.

13.verse: Once that distraction was removed, all the soldiers followed Joab to find Sheba, son of Bichri.

14.verse: Sheba marched across all the tribal lands of Israel until he came to Abel in Beth-maacah; and all his kinsmen, the Berites, gathered and followed him inside the fortified city.

15.verse: When Joab’s army arrived, they put Abel Beth-maacah under siege. They built an earthen rampart up onto the wall, while others with Joab tried to break the wall down.

16.verse: Then a wise woman called out from the city. Woman: Listen to me! Tell Joab that I want to talk to him!

17.verse: Joab came close enough to hear her. Woman: Are you Joab? Joab: Yes, I am. Woman: I, your servant, have something to tell you. Joab: All right. I am listening.

18.verse: Woman: In the old days, people used to say, “Let’s ask for guidance at Abel,” and there they would resolve their differences.

19.verse: I am one of the many in Israel who are faithful and peaceful. Why would you destroy a city that has been a mother to Israel? Why would you knock down what the Eternal One has built?

20.verse: Joab: I’m certainly not here to destroy the city.

21.verse: That’s the last thing I want to do! But we are pursuing a man from the hill country of Ephraim: Sheba, Bichri’s son, who has raised up a rebellion against David the king. If you will hand him over to us, then we will lift the siege and go home. Woman: Then stay alert—we’ll throw his head over the wall to you.

22.verse: The wise woman talked to all the people about her plan to save the city. They cut off Sheba’s head and threw it over the wall for Joab. Then Joab blew the trumpet to halt his attack. The troops went to their homes, and Joab returned to the king at Jerusalem.

23.verse: With Amasa dead, Joab again commanded all the army of Israel. Benaiah, Jehoiada’s son, commanded the mercenary companies of Cherethites and Pelethites.

24.verse: Adoram commanded all the forced laborers. Jehoshaphat, Ahilud’s son, was the recorder,

25.verse: and Sheva was the royal secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were priests,

26.verse: and Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.

1.verse: After the people had suffered from a famine for three successive years, David asked the Eternal One why the famine lingered, and the answer came that the nation was guilty for not making amends for the bloodlust of King Saul, who slaughtered the people of Gibeon.

2.verse: (The Gibeonites were not from Israel—they were related to the Amorites. Saul tried to annihilate them in his zeal for Israel and Judah, although the people of Israel had promised to spare them during the days of Joshua.) So David called for the leaders of Gibeon.

3.verse: David: What can I do, what can I give you, to lift this guilt from my land so that you will honor the Eternal’s chosen people?

4.verse: Gibeonite Leaders: Silver and gold won’t make things right for us with Saul’s kingdom. And it is not for us to tell you who should be subject to capital punishment in Israel. David: I will do whatever you ask.

5.verse: Gibeonite Leaders: Saul attacked us and tried to destroy us, to wipe us off the map of Israel.

6.verse: Give us seven of his descendants, and we will hang them on a tree in Gibeah before the Eternal, on His mountain. David: I will give them to you.

7.verse: Now the king did not give them Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson and Jonathan’s son, because of the sacred oath between David and Jonathan.

8.verse: But he did take Saul’s two sons by Rizpah (daughter of Aiah), Armoni and Mephibosheth, and the five sons of Merab (Saul’s daughter) that she had by Adriel (son of Barzillai the Meholathite).

9.verse: David had them seized and handed them over to the Gibeonites, who executed them before the Eternal One on the mountain. All seven of them died together, in the spring of the year during the first days of the barley harvest.

10.verse: Rizpah, Aiah’s daughter, spread out sackcloth on a rock to make a place to sit; and from the time her sons died until rain fell in late autumn, she refused to let the birds or wild animals desecrate the bodies.

11.verse: When David heard what Saul’s concubine Rizpah had done,

12.verse: he went and gathered the bones of Saul and Jonathan (which the people of Jabesh-gilead had stolen from the place where they were hanged in the Philistine public square in Beth-shan on the day the Philistines killed Saul on Gilboa).

13.verse: He took the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son and gathered the bones of those who had been impaled in Gibeon.

14.verse: He had Saul and Jonathan buried in the tomb of their father Kish, in Zela in the land of Benjamin. All that David commanded was done; and afterward, God answered the prayers of the people of Israel for the land.

15.verse: Philistia and Israel were at war again, and David and his soldiers fought them long and hard until at last he grew weary.

16.verse: Then Ishbi-benob (who was a descendant of Raphah) announced that he had come to kill David. He carried a bronze spear, the head of which weighed nearly 10 pounds, and he carried a new sword.

17.verse: But Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, came to David’s aid. He attacked and killed this Philistine. David’s Men (to David): You can’t go out to fight with us any longer. If you are killed, then the lamp of Israel will go out.

18.verse: Later the Israelites fought the Philistines at Gob; and Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, another Philistine warrior descended from the giant.

19.verse: In another fight at Gob with the Philistines, Elhanan (son of Jaare-oregim of Bethlehem), killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was as large as a weaver’s beam.

20.verse: Then in a battle at Gath, they fought against another famous warrior. He was a huge man with 6 fingers on each hand and 6 toes on each foot—24 in all—and he was also descended from the giant.

21.verse: When he insulted the people of Israel, Jonathan (the son of David’s brother Shimei) killed him.

22.verse: All four of these great warriors were descended from the giant of Gath, but all of them were defeated by the skill of David and his men.

1.verse: David composed the following song of praise to the Eternal because He delivered him from all of his enemies and especially from Saul.

2.verse: At last the day comes when David has conquered—at least, temporarily—all his enemies, and he marks this day by rejoicing. In the same way that he composed songs to lament Saul’s and Jonathan’s deaths, David composes a psalm of joy to the Lord who is his strong fortress and his security. He gives God the credit, but he also claims—and rightly, of course, in spite of his occasional transgressions—that he has tried to do what God asked him to do, has tried to keep the ways of God. David: The Eternal is my rock, my fortress, and my savior;

3.verse: He is my True God, my stronghold in whom I take refuge, My strong shield, my horn that calls forth rescue, my tall-walled tower and strong refuge, My savior from violence.

4.verse: I call on the Eternal, who is worthy to be praised, and I have been rescued from my enemies.

5.verse: The waves of death surrounded me; the torrents of terror tugged at me.

6.verse: The sorrows of the grave tightly tangled me; the snares of death met me.

7.verse: In my time of need I called upon the Eternal One; I called to my True God for help. He heard my voice from His temple, and my cry came to His ears.

8.verse: Because of His great anger, the earth shook and staggered; the foundations of the heavens trembled and quaked.

9.verse: Smoke billowed out from His nostrils and devouring fire from His mouth; glowing coals flamed from Him.

10.verse: He bent the heavens and descended; darkness is beneath His feet.

11.verse: He rode upon a heavenly creature, flying; He soared swiftly on the wings of the wind.

12.verse: He placed darkness around Him like a canopy and made His home in dark watery clouds of the sky.

13.verse: Out from His brightness, hailstones and burning coals flared forth.

14.verse: The Eternal thundered in the heavens, the voice of the Most High speaking.

15.verse: He shot forth His arrows and scattered the wicked; He flung forth His lightning and struck them.

16.verse: Then the deepest channels of the seas were revealed; and the foundations of the world were uncovered At Your rebuke, O Eternal One, at the blast of wind breathed from Your nostrils.

17.verse: He reached down from above me, He held me; He pulled me from the raging waters.

18.verse: He rescued me from my strong enemy and from all those who hated me, for they would have overwhelmed me.

19.verse: When my enemies came for me on the day of my destruction, the Eternal stepped in to support me.

20.verse: He led me out onto a broad plain; He delivered me because of His delight in me.

21.verse: The Eternal One rewarded me because I sought righteousness; He rewarded me because I kept my hands clean.

22.verse: He rewarded me because I kept the ways of the Eternal and have not walked away from my True God in wickedness.

23.verse: For all His laws were there before me, and I did not push His statutes away.

24.verse: I made myself blameless before Him; I kept myself from guilt and shame.

25.verse: That’s why the Eternal has rewarded me for seeking righteousness; He’s rewarded me because He sees I have remained pure.

26.verse: To the good, You show Your goodness; to the blameless, You prove to be blameless;

27.verse: To the pure, You show Your purity; to the crooked, You make Yourself twisted.

28.verse: For You rescue weak people, but the proud You bring low.

29.verse: You are the lamp who lights my way, O Eternal One, the Eternal, who lights up my darkness.

30.verse: With Your help, I can conquer an army; with Your help, I can vault over walls.

31.verse: God has made an upright way; the promise of the Eternal rings true; He stands and shields all who hide in Him.

32.verse: Who is the True God except the Eternal One? Who stands like a rock except our God?

33.verse: The True God who circled me with strength puts the upright on His way.

34.verse: He made me sure-footed as a deer and placed me high up and safe.

35.verse: He teaches me to fight so that my arms can bend a bronze bow.

36.verse: You have given me the shield of Your salvation, and Your support has made me strong.

37.verse: You taught me how to walk with care so my feet would not slip.

38.verse: I pursued my enemies and defeated them and did not stop until all were destroyed.

39.verse: When I eliminated them, they fell down beneath my feet so they could not rise again.

40.verse: For You equipped me with strength for battle, and You made my enemies fall beneath me.

41.verse: You made my enemies turn and run, and all who hated me, I destroyed.

42.verse: They looked everywhere, but no one came to save them; they asked the Eternal for help, but He did not answer them.

43.verse: I beat them until they were as small as the dust of the earth; I flung them away and beat them down like mud in the gutters.

44.verse: You delivered me from conflict with the peoples; you raised me up to rule over nations; people whom I did not know came to serve me.

45.verse: Strangers came to me, cringing and afraid; as soon as they heard about me, they obeyed me.

46.verse: Strangers had their courage shrivel before them and came fearfully to me from behind their high walls.

47.verse: The Eternal One is alive! May my Rock be blessed; and the True God, the Rock of my deliverance be exalted,

48.verse: The God who avenged me and tamed the peoples under me,

49.verse: Who rescued me from all my foes. You raised me up above my enemies; You saved me from the violent ones.

50.verse: For this, I will praise You, O Eternal One, among the nations and sing praises to Your name.

51.verse: He is a tower of salvation for His king and shows His loyal love to His anointed, to David and his descendants, continually.

1.verse: Here are the last words of David, son of Jesse: the words of the one raised up, the anointed one of Jacob’s True God, the sweet songwriter of Israel.

2.verse: David: The Spirit of the Eternal speaks through me; His voice emerges from my mouth.

3.verse: The God of Israel has talked to me; and the Rock of Israel said, “One who rules people with justice and who leads them in the fear of God

4.verse: Is like the morning light, the sun rising on a cloudless morning, and the shining grasslands brought up from rain.”

5.verse: Isn’t this how God has raised up my house? Because He has made a perpetual covenant with me, well-ordered and secure, Won’t He make all things to grow and prosper, save me, and give me all I desire?

6.verse: But the wicked are like thorns cut off and tossed away that can’t be picked up with your hands;

7.verse: No, to touch them, use the iron tip on the shaft of a spear. They are burned up on the spot.

8.verse: David has been brought up from his position as a lowly shepherd, the youngest son in the household, to the pinnacle of success by his faith in God and his own willingness to follow God. It has been an adventure fraught with danger and intrigue, and marked with loss and heartbreak along the way. David’s own failings find themselves reflected—and magnified—in his children. But here is one of the high points of the story of the people of God, united at last under a powerful and beloved king, and victorious against their enemies. Here is a list of the warriors who fought for David: Josheb-basshebeth the Tahchemonite was the most powerful of David’s three most-honored warriors; he took up his spear and killed 800 in one battle.

9.verse: The next of David’s three mighty men was Eleazar, son of Dodo of Ahohi. Eleazar stood with David when they defied the Philistines who had gathered there to fight. The Israelites retreated,

10.verse: but Eleazar stood his ground. He killed Philistine soldiers that day until his arm grew tired, but he never dropped his sword. The Eternal One gave them a decisive victory that day; and then the people came back, only to pillage the fallen.

11.verse: Last of these top three was Shammah, son of Agee of Harar. The Philistines gathered at Lehi where there was a field full of lentils, and the Israelites fled from them.

12.verse: But Shammah stood in the center of the field and fought, killing many Philistines; and the Eternal gave His people a great victory.

13.verse: At the beginning of harvest, these top three of David’s thirty chief warriors joined David at the cave of Adullam. A group of Philistines was camped in the valley of Rephaim,

14.verse: David was hiding in his safe place, and the main force of the Philistines was quartered in Bethlehem.

15.verse: David (with longing): I wish someone would bring me some water to drink from the well of Bethlehem by the gate!

16.verse: So these three mighty men broke through the nearby camp of the Philistines, drew water from the Bethlehem well that was by the gate, and brought it back for David. But he would not drink it; instead he poured it out, although he was parched with thirst, as a drink offering to the Eternal One.

17.verse: David: O Eternal God, I have no right to drink this water. It would be like drinking the blood of the men who risked their lives for it! So he did not drink it. This is the kind of thing the three mighty men did for David.

18.verse: Besides the three highest ranking soldiers, there was Abishai (Zeruiah’s son and the brother of Joab), who was commander of the elite force of 30. With his spear he killed 300 men in battle and won honor as the three did.

19.verse: Abishai was the most honored of the 30 and became their commander, but he did not become one of the three.

20.verse: And there was Benaiah (Jehoiada’s son), son of a great man from Kabzeel, who also did great deeds. He struck down two lionhearted heroes of Moab. Benaiah also killed a lion in a pit one snowy day,

21.verse: and he killed an Egyptian who was a powerful-looking man. The Egyptian was armed with a spear while Benaiah had only his staff, but he took the spear away from him and killed the Egyptian with his own weapon.

22.verse: These were the kinds of feats Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, performed that won him a name equal to the three mighty men for bravery.

23.verse: He was famous among the 30, but never became one of the three. David made him the captain of his personal guard.

24.verse: These are the warriors who were counted among the 30: Asahel, Joab’s brother; Elhanan, son of Dodo of Bethlehem;

25.verse: Shammah of Harod; Elika of Harod;

26.verse: Helez the Paltite; Ira, son of Ikkesh of Tekoa;

27.verse: Abiezer of Anathoth; Mebunnai the Hushathite;

28.verse: Zalmon the Ahohite; Maharai of Netophah;

29.verse: Heleb, son of Baanah of Netophah; Ittai, son of Ribai of Gibeah in Benjamin;

30.verse: Benaiah of Pirathon; Hiddai of the waters of Gaash;

31.verse: Abi-albon the Arbathite; Azmaveth of Barhum;

32.verse: Eliahba of Shaalbon; Jashen the Gimzonite; Jonathan, son of

33.verse: Shammah of Harar; Ahiam, son of Sharar of Harar;

34.verse: Eliphelet, son of Ahasbai of Maacah; Eliam, son of Ahithophel the Gilonite;

35.verse: Hezro of Carmel; Paarai the Arbite;

36.verse: Igal, son of Nathan of Zobah; Bani the Gadite;

37.verse: Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai of Beeroth; the armor-bearer of Joab, Zeruiah’s son;

38.verse: Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite;

39.verse: Uriah the Hittite—37 men in all who were counted among the 30.

1.verse: Once again the Eternal grew angry with Israel; so He used David against them, telling the king to go and count the people of Israel and Judah.

2.verse: David spoke to Joab, the commander of his army who was with him. David: Travel to all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and take a census of the people. I want to know how many there are.

3.verse: But Joab cautioned the king. Joab: May the Eternal God increase the number of your people a hundred times while you are still alive to see it. But why on earth would you desire to do this, my king?

4.verse: But the king’s order held, and Joab and the other leaders of the army left the king’s presence and went out to count the people of Israel.

5.verse: To begin, they went over the Jordan River and camped at Aroer south of the city that is in the middle of the valley there. Then they moved on toward Gad and Jazer.

6.verse: After that, they traveled to Gilead and to Tahtim-hodshi; then they traveled on north to Dan-jaan, and from Dan they went west to Sidon

7.verse: and then to the fortified city of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites. Then they went south to the wilderness of Judah at Beersheba.

8.verse: At last, when they had traveled through all the land, they came back to Jerusalem after 9 months and 20 days.

9.verse: Joab reported these astonishing numbers to the king: Israel had 800,000 soldiers and Judah had 500,000.

10.verse: After he heard this, David was overwhelmed with guilt for counting his subjects. He prayed to the Eternal One. David: I have committed a great wrong against You. But please, O Eternal One, take away the guilt I feel, for I have done a stupid thing.

11.verse: When David rose the next morning, he was met by the prophet Gad, David’s seer, who had received a message from the Eternal.

12.verse: Gad: I am supposed to tell you this: “The Eternal says, ‘I will offer you three choices. Pick one, and that will be what I will do to you.’” Do you want to have seven years of famine in the land? Would you rather be on the run from your enemies for three months? Or shall a plague rage for three days through the land? Make a choice, and tell me what answer to give to the One who sent me.

13.verse: Gad: I am supposed to tell you this: “The Eternal says, ‘I will offer you three choices. Pick one, and that will be what I will do to you.’” Do you want to have seven years of famine in the land? Would you rather be on the run from your enemies for three months? Or shall a plague rage for three days through the land? Make a choice, and tell me what answer to give to the One who sent me.

14.verse: David: This is horrible! But I would rather fall by the hand of the Eternal, because He is merciful, than fall into human hands.

15.verse: So the Eternal One sent a great plague that morning and for three days. It swept through Israel from Dan in the far north to Beersheba in the desert south, killing 70,000 people.

16.verse: But when the heavenly messenger prepared to destroy Jerusalem, He relented; and He commanded the heavenly messenger who had brought the epidemic. Eternal One: Stop. That is enough. The heavenly messenger then paused beside the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite;

17.verse: and when David saw him there, the one striking the people, he spoke to the Eternal One. David: Look, I am the one who offended You, the only one who has done wrong. What have these innocent sheep done? If someone is going to be punished for what I did, it should be me and my family. Punish us.

18.verse: Later that day, the prophet Gad approached David. Gad: Go, and build an altar to the Eternal on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

19.verse: So David went to perform this task the Eternal had given him through Gad.

20.verse: Araunah saw the king and his men coming toward him, so he went out into the road and bowed low before him in the dust.

21.verse: Araunah: Why has my lord, the king, come to see your servant? David: I have come to buy your threshing floor. We must build an altar to the Eternal there so that this epidemic will be lifted from the people.

22.verse: Araunah: My lord and king, take and offer what seems right. Here are the oxen you need to make the burnt offering. Take the threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for firewood.

23.verse: I will give you all these things, my king. May the Eternal One your God look on your offering with favor.

24.verse: David: No, I will buy these things from you. Name your price. I will not make an offering to the Eternal One, my True God, that has cost me nothing.

25.verse: David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for 20 ounces of silver. He built an altar there to the Eternal and made burnt and peace offerings on it. The Eternal One heard David’s prayers for the land and lifted the plague from Israel.
